license.license-p: This is an open-access book distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited. The citation of this article must include: the name(s) of the authors, the name of the journal, the full URL of the article (in a hyperlinked format if distributed online) and the DOI number of the article.

abstract.p: This is a sample abstract that forms part of the bookMetadataSample.xml file.

notes.title: Editorial Notes
notes.p: This is a sample editorial note.

fn.p: For a general and brief introduction and selection of texts, cf. Skjærvø 2011; Boyce 2006.
A short bibliography on this matter is found in Taylor 2008, 1–2.
For a general overview of Sasanian art cf. Christensen 1944, and even if in some aspects are superseded cf. Harper 1978; Yarshater 1983, chapter 29 on Sasanian art; Harper 1987, 585–94.

For an overview on the history of Iran in the Sasanian Era cf. Erdmann 1937; Gyselen 1995; Daryaee 2008. For a sociological-historical overview cf. Daryaee 2009; and for a very brief but informative introduction in German cf. Schippmann 1990.
For some aspects of cultural exchanges between Sasanians and Romans cf. Canepa 2009.
On Ahura Mazdā cf. Boyce 19851, 684–7.
On amǝṣ̌a spǝṇta cf. Boyce 19852, 933–6; Narten 1982.
On frauuaṣ̌i cf. Boyce 2001, 195–9.
Also cf. Boyce 19852, 933–6.

In ŠnŠ XV.5 we can read: “(In) that material world of Mine, I who am Ōhrmazd, (preside over) the just man, and Wohuman over cattle, and Ardwahišt over fire, and Šahrewar over metals, and Spandarmad over earth and virtuous woman, and Hordad over waters, and Amurdad over plants.” Cf. Kotwal 1969, 58–9.
For the evidences regardings this link cf. Boyce19852, 933–6.
Bundahišn VIa.2–3, cf. Pakzad 2005, 89–90.
Pokorny considers Yazata-, yaz-, yasna, yájati, yajñá, ἅγιος to all be derivatives of a Proto-Indo-European (PIE) root i̪agʲ- (i̪ag´-) “religiös verehren” (“religiously venerate”), cf. Pokorny 1959.
On investiture and investiture scenes cf. Brosius et al. 2006, 180–8.
For more details on different views—secular, religious, or erotic—regarding the “dancing girl” cf. Ettinghausen1967,and alsoSarre 1922; also Bier 1985, 1009–11, 1.
Īwān (NP ایوان) is a typically Iranian rectangular type of construction, which consists of a vaulted rectangular hall, walled on three sides and open on one end. Cf. Grabar 1989, 153–5.
However, not discussed in this paper, there is another group of nude, wingless, male figures which I identify as personifications of “apąm napāt.”
Cf. Ettinghausen1967.
Although associated with silver vessels made in Iran during the Sassanian dynasty (224–651 CE), the vessel’s shape and decoration suggest that this object dates from the early Islamic era.
Cf. Harper 1981, Pl. 36.
The dancing female figures are identified as being either totally or partially female nudes in erotic scenes, cf. Ghirshman 1953, 54.
In the hierarchical imagery system of the art of ancient orientals, the proportions of the figures, as well as objects in some cases, are crucial in declaring the significance of power.
Cf. Ettinghausen 1967, 28–29, plate 1–4.
Cf. Martiniani-Reber and Bénazeth 1997, 105, plate 43.
Cf. Martiniani-Reber and Bénazeth 1997, 105, plate 43. The goddess is also reponsible for the warriors. No attribute of this aspect of her in this context is available.
barǝsman or barsom is the sacred twig bundle which is an important part of the Zoroastrian liturgical apparatus, cf. Kanga 1989, 825–7.
For a detailed description of the capitals cf.Stock 1996.
On the Babylonian-Akkadian goddess cf. Zgoll 2003; Wegner 1991; Meinhold 2009; Levit-Tawil 1992.
With the exception of the armed mounted figure on the upper part of the greater grotto of Tāq-e Bostān.
Cf. Vanden Berghe1984; Kleiss and Boehmer1996, as well as the very detailed and valuable four volumes by Fukai and Horiuchi1969, 1972, 1983, and 1984.

For the links and connections between Tāq-e Bostān and Byzantin iconography cf. Mackintosh 1978; also cf. Fukai et al. 1984, 167–77 (Appendix II: Flying Victory—Its Prototypes and Diffusion). Tanabe asserts that “It is clear that the flying genii are obviously modelled after the goddesses Nike and Tyche, but her significance within the Sasanian dynastic iconography is unknown.” Cf. Harrison1978, 43; this must be disscused in a separate article as despite Tanabe’s opinion, the iconographical role and significance of these flying figures is rather clear.
For a more detailed description cf. Harrison1978, 42ff.
xᶹarǝnah, lit. “glory” is themagic force or power of luminous and fiery nature. On xᶹarǝnah cf. Gnoli 1999, 312–9.
Tanabe mentioned this possibility only marginally and in a footnote, but does not discuss it. Cf. Harrison1978, 46, n. 21.
Cf. Werner 1990, 161, n. 47, and the author’s observations and dialoges with Irani Zoroastrians.
For a descriptive account on frauuaṣ̌is cf. Dhalla 1972, 143–50; Boyce 2001, 195–9.
See also in Bundahišn VIa.3, cf. Soraki 2005, 90.
